trans-unit.source: How to Use the Engagement API on Android
trans-unit.target: How to Use the Engagement API on Android

trans-unit.source: Latest Android SDK - How to Use the Engagement API on Android
trans-unit.target: Latest Android SDK - How to Use the Engagement API on Android

trans-unit.source: How to Use the Engagement API on Android
trans-unit.target: How to Use the Engagement API on Android

trans-unit.source: This document is an add-on to the document [How to Integrate Engagement on Android](mobile-engagement-android-integrate-engagement.md).
trans-unit.target: This document is an add-on to the document [How to Integrate Engagement on Android](mobile-engagement-android-integrate-engagement.md).

trans-unit.source: It provides in depth details about how to use the Engagement API to report your application statistics.
trans-unit.target: It provides in depth details about how to use the Engagement API to report your application statistics.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that if you only want Engagement to report your application's sessions, activities, crashes and technical information, then the simplest way is to make all your `Activity` sub-classes inherit from the corresponding `EngagementActivity` class.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that if you only want Engagement to report your application's sessions, activities, crashes and technical information, then the simplest way is to make all your `Activity` sub-classes inherit from the corresponding `EngagementActivity` class.

trans-unit.source: If you want to do more, for example if you need to report application specific events, errors and jobs, or if you have to report your application's activities in a different way than the one implemented in the `EngagementActivity` classes, then you need to use the Engagement API.
trans-unit.target: If you want to do more, for example if you need to report application specific events, errors and jobs, or if you have to report your application's activities in a different way than the one implemented in the `EngagementActivity` classes, then you need to use the Engagement API.

trans-unit.source: The Engagement API is provided by the `EngagementAgent` class.
trans-unit.target: The Engagement API is provided by the `EngagementAgent` class.

trans-unit.source: An instance of this class can be retrieved by calling the `EngagementAgent.getInstance(Context)` static method (note that the `EngagementAgent` object returned is a singleton).
trans-unit.target: An instance of this class can be retrieved by calling the `EngagementAgent.getInstance(Context)` static method (note that the `EngagementAgent` object returned is a singleton).

trans-unit.source: Engagement concepts
trans-unit.target: Engagement concepts

trans-unit.source: The following parts refine the common [Mobile Engagement Concepts](mobile-engagement-concepts.md), for the Android platform.
trans-unit.target: The following parts refine the common [Mobile Engagement Concepts](mobile-engagement-concepts.md), for the Android platform.

trans-unit.source: `Session` and `Activity`
trans-unit.target: `Session` and `Activity`

trans-unit.source: If the user stays more than a few seconds idle between two *activities*, then his sequence of *activities* is split in two distinct *sessions*.
trans-unit.target: If the user stays more than a few seconds idle between two *activities*, then his sequence of *activities* is split in two distinct *sessions*.

trans-unit.source: These few seconds are called the "session timeout".
trans-unit.target: These few seconds are called the "session timeout".

trans-unit.source: An *activity* is usually associated with one screen of the application, that is to say the *activity* starts when the screen is displayed and stops when the screen is closed: this is the case when the Engagement SDK is integrated by using the `EngagementActivity` classes.
trans-unit.target: An *activity* is usually associated with one screen of the application, that is to say the *activity* starts when the screen is displayed and stops when the screen is closed: this is the case when the Engagement SDK is integrated by using the `EngagementActivity` classes.

trans-unit.source: But *activities* can also be controlled manually by using the Engagement API.
trans-unit.target: But *activities* can also be controlled manually by using the Engagement API.

trans-unit.source: This allows to split a given screen in several sub parts to get more details about the usage of this screen (for example to known how often and how long dialogs are used inside this screen).
trans-unit.target: This allows to split a given screen in several sub parts to get more details about the usage of this screen (for example to known how often and how long dialogs are used inside this screen).

trans-unit.source: Reporting Activities
trans-unit.target: Reporting Activities

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] You don't need to report activities like described in this section if you are using the `EngagementActivity` class and its variants as explained in the How to Integrate Engagement on Android document.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] You don't need to report activities like described in this section if you are using the `EngagementActivity` class and its variants as explained in the How to Integrate Engagement on Android document.

trans-unit.source: User starts a new Activity
trans-unit.target: User starts a new Activity

trans-unit.source: You need to call `startActivity()` each time the user activity changes.
trans-unit.target: You need to call `startActivity()` each time the user activity changes.

trans-unit.source: The first call to this function starts a new user session.
trans-unit.target: The first call to this function starts a new user session.

trans-unit.source: The best place to call this function is on each activity `onResume` callback.
trans-unit.target: The best place to call this function is on each activity `onResume` callback.

trans-unit.source: User ends his current Activity
trans-unit.target: User ends his current Activity

trans-unit.source: You need to call `endActivity()` at least once when the user finishes his last activity.
trans-unit.target: You need to call `endActivity()` at least once when the user finishes his last activity.

trans-unit.source: This informs the Engagement SDK that the user is currently idle, and that the user session need to be closed once the session timeout will expire (if you call `startActivity()` before the session timeout expires, the session is simply resumed).
trans-unit.target: This informs the Engagement SDK that the user is currently idle, and that the user session need to be closed once the session timeout will expire (if you call `startActivity()` before the session timeout expires, the session is simply resumed).

trans-unit.source: The best place to call this function is on each activity `onPause` callback.
trans-unit.target: The best place to call this function is on each activity `onPause` callback.

trans-unit.source: Reporting Events during a job
trans-unit.target: Reporting Events during a job

trans-unit.source: Events can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.
trans-unit.target: Events can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Suppose we have a social network, and we use a job to report the total time during which the user is connected to the server.
trans-unit.target: Suppose we have a social network, and we use a job to report the total time during which the user is connected to the server.

trans-unit.source: The user can stay connected in background even when he's using another application or when the phone is sleeping, so there is no session.
trans-unit.target: The user can stay connected in background even when he's using another application or when the phone is sleeping, so there is no session.

trans-unit.source: The user can receive messages from his friends, this is a job event.
trans-unit.target: The user can receive messages from his friends, this is a job event.

trans-unit.source: Extra parameters
trans-unit.target: Extra parameters

trans-unit.source: Arbitrary data can be attached to events, errors, activities and jobs.
trans-unit.target: Arbitrary data can be attached to events, errors, activities and jobs.

trans-unit.source: This data can be structured, it uses Android's Bundle class (actually, it works like extra parameters in Android Intents).
trans-unit.target: This data can be structured, it uses Android's Bundle class (actually, it works like extra parameters in Android Intents).

trans-unit.source: Note that a Bundle can contain arrays or another Bundle instances.
trans-unit.target: Note that a Bundle can contain arrays or another Bundle instances.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] If you put in parcelable or serializable parameters, make sure their `toString()` method is implemented to return a human-readable string.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] If you put in parcelable or serializable parameters, make sure their `toString()` method is implemented to return a human-readable string.

trans-unit.source: Serializable classes that contain non transient fields that are not serializable will make Android crash when you will call `bundle.putSerializable("key",value);`
trans-unit.target: Serializable classes that contain non transient fields that are not serializable will make Android crash when you will call `bundle.putSerializable("key",value);`

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Sparse arrays in extra parameters are not supported, that is, it won't be serialized as an array.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Sparse arrays in extra parameters are not supported, that is, it won't be serialized as an array.

trans-unit.source: You should convert them into standard arrays before using it in extra parameters.
trans-unit.target: You should convert them into standard arrays before using it in extra parameters.

trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: Limits
trans-unit.target: Limits

trans-unit.source: Keys
trans-unit.target: Keys

trans-unit.source: Each key in the `Bundle` must match the following regular expression:
trans-unit.target: Each key in the `Bundle` must match the following regular expression:

trans-unit.source: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).
trans-unit.target: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).

trans-unit.source: Size
trans-unit.target: Size

trans-unit.source: Extras are limited to **1024** characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement service).
trans-unit.target: Extras are limited to **1024** characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement service).

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, the JSON sent to the server is 58 characters long:
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, the JSON sent to the server is 58 characters long:

trans-unit.source: Reporting Application Information
trans-unit.target: Reporting Application Information

trans-unit.source: You can manually report tracking information (or any other application specific information) using the `sendAppInfo()` function.
trans-unit.target: You can manually report tracking information (or any other application specific information) using the `sendAppInfo()` function.

trans-unit.source: Note that these information can be sent incrementally: only the latest value for a given key will be kept for a given device.
trans-unit.target: Note that these information can be sent incrementally: only the latest value for a given key will be kept for a given device.

trans-unit.source: Like event extras, the Bundle class is used to abstract application information, note that arrays or sub-bundles will be treated as flat strings (using JSON serialization).
trans-unit.target: Like event extras, the Bundle class is used to abstract application information, note that arrays or sub-bundles will be treated as flat strings (using JSON serialization).

trans-unit.target: Example
